Class StringUtil

      • toLines

        public static java.util.List<java.lang.String> toLines(java.lang.String text,
                                       boolean preserveDelimiters)
        Parses the lines of the given text. Lines are delimited by "\r", "\n" or "\r\n". If preserveDelimiters is true: For each line, this function returns a pair of strings: line content, newline character(s). Returned newline delimiters are: "\r", "\n", "\r\n", or "". If preserveDelimiters is false: The function returns the list of line contents, without newline characters.
        Parameters:
        text - The text to convert to lines.
        Returns:
        Lines optionally with delimiters, or null if input was null.
        See Also:
        toText(List)

      • toText

        public static java.lang.String toText(java.util.List<java.lang.String> lines)
        Creates a single String by concatenating a given list of string together with newline-characters. This function is the reverse-function of toLines(String, boolean)
        Parameters:
        lines -
        Returns:
        lines joined with \r\n to one string
        See Also:
        toLines(String, boolean)

        public static java.lang.String toHexColonFormat(java.lang.Object x)
        Formats an Integer or Long into MAC/FC colon format, e.g. a Long value of 5766308467535143428 gets transformed to 50:06:0b:00:00:c2:62:04
        Parameters:
        x, - a String, Long or Integer
        Returns:
        given object in hex format with colons

      • levenshteinDistance

        public static int levenshteinDistance(java.lang.String s,
                      java.lang.String t)
        computes the edit distance between two strings. This is the number of edits (insertion, deletion, or substitution) required to transform s1 into s2 code taken from Levenshtein_distance
        Parameters:
        s - string one
        t - string two
        Returns:
        distance between 2 strings based on Levenshtein algorithm

      • between

        public static java.lang.String between(java.lang.String s,
                       java.lang.String start,
                       java.lang.String end)
        convenience function to return the contents between two delimiters. Example: between( "123", "1", "3" ) returns 2

        start - starting delimiter
        end - ending delimiter
        Returns:
        string X in the first part of s which matches startXend, null if there is no match

      • split

        public static com.fluidops.util.Pair<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> split(java.lang.String s,
                                                              java.lang.String delimiter)
        convenience for String.split(s,delim) for cases where [first,second] is returned
        Parameters:
        s - string to tokenize: example: first,second,third
        delimiter - char to use when tokenizing
        Returns:
        string parted into first and second: example: split( "first,second,third", "," ) = {"first", "second,third"}

        Returns:

      • splitDomainAndUser

        public static java.lang.String[] splitDomainAndUser(java.lang.String username)
        Parameters:
        username - The user either in the DOMAIN\USERNAME or the USERNAME@DOMAIN syntax
        Returns:
        A String array with two fields.
        [0] contains the domain
        [1] the username.
        We always return a string array with the length == 2. So it can be that we return an empty string in one or both fields.

      • encodeAsAsciiPathName

        public static java.lang.String encodeAsAsciiPathName(java.lang.String source)
        Make sure that the returned string contains only characters allowed in path names, while still being unique to the source name. Example MÃ¼ller and MÃ¶ller (with umlauts) should return different strings.

        Unencoded characters are 'A'-'Z', 'a'-'z', '0'-'9', '-', '_', '.', everything else is replaced with '_<hexcode>'

        Parameters:
        source - source text
        Returns:
        encoded text

      • containsNonIriRefCharacter

        public static boolean containsNonIriRefCharacter(java.lang.String s,
                                 boolean allowBrackets)
        Checks if the string contains a character that is invalid in IRI_refs (according to the W3C SPARQL definition, see http://www.w3.org/TR/rdf-sparql-query/#rIRI_REF). This is basically a sanity check determining whether a user string qualifies for translation into a IRI_REF, i.e. can be converted to a valid URI. It should be used wherever the user can input (parts of) a URI.
        Parameters:
        s - the input string
        allowBrackets - whether or not to allow < and > brackets in the URI

                                         char replacementCharacter)

        Parameters:

        replacementCharacter - the characters that replaces all non-valid IRI characters
        Returns:
        String with all non-valid IRI characters replaced
